awd_titl_txt: NRT-IGE: Reducing Attrition of Underrepresented Minority and First-Generation Graduate Students in Interdisciplinary Computational Sciences
awd_abstract_narration:
This National Science Foundation Research Traineeship (NRT) award in the Innovations in Graduate Education (IGE) Track to the University of California, Merced will pilot a graduate education innovation in Interdisciplinary Computational Sciences (ICS) to reduce attrition rates, particularly for underrepresented minorities and first-generation students for whom degree completion is a particular challenge. The project will undertake a systematic, integrated approach that provides team-based interdisciplinary research and student support and mentoring. Another central element of this approach is career preparation for research positions in industry and national laboratories, as well as academia. Project evaluation will examine implementation, student achievement, and retention and will use formative assessment to guide refinements. If successful, this pilot project will result in an educational approach that improves doctoral completion rates for underrepresented groups and improves career preparedness, and that is scalable and replicable to additional programs and institutions.

The primary goals of the pilot program are to foster computational and data analytic skills within an interdisciplinary framework; reduce attrition, especially among underrepresented minorities and first generation graduate students; and prepare students for careers in, or in partnership with, national laboratories and industry. Program activities in support of the goals include a two-day introductory workshop followed by weekly project meetings and instructional modules focused on specific skills required to solve interdisciplinary computational science problems. Module content will include programming languages, tools for data analytics, model building, fundamental algorithms, and data interpretation and visualization. In addition, the program will provide professional development modules focused on project management, teamwork, communication and presentation skills.  All of the modules will be complemented with continuous mentoring from faculty, peers, and partners from industry and the national laboratories. This pilot project offers students the opportunity to move away from narrow disciplinary training, broadening their approaches to problem solving and their ability to work in diverse teams while also expanding their computational skills and familiarity with data analytic tools. Assessment will evaluate the success of instructional modules and the structure and pedagogical strategy of the project as a whole, with formative assessments informing revisions in an iterative process. It is expected that the interdisciplinary team-based approach employed in this project, in combination with professional development, social supports and multiple mentors, will result in improved completion rates for underrepresented minority and first generation STEM graduate students and prepare them for future career success, thus helping to meet a serious national need.

The NSF Research Traineeship (NRT) Program is designed to encourage the development and implementation of bold, new, potentially transformative models for STEM graduate education training. The Innovations in Graduate Education Track is dedicated solely to piloting, testing, and evaluating novel, innovative, and potentially transformative approaches to graduate education.

por.por_cntn:
?NRT-IGE: Reducing Attrition in Underrepresented Minority and First-Generation Graduate Students in Interdisciplinary Computational Sciences? was designed to reduce attrition rates, particularly for underrepresented minorities (URM) and first-generation students (FGS) for whom degree completion is a particular challenge. Our fundamental innovation was a systematic, integrated approach to increasing completion rates among URM and FGS graduate students in computational science-related fields. Central to our approach was preparation for research positions in industry and the national laboratories, as well as academia. More specifically, our program goals were to:

  • Foster computational and data analytic skills;
  • Reduce attrition, especially among URM and FGS;
  • Nurture an interdisciplinary mindset;
  • Prepare students for careers in, or partnerships with, national laboratories and industry.

We hypothesized that an interdisciplinary team-based approach, in combination with social supports and multiple mentors, would result in improved completion rates for URM and FGS STEM graduate students and prepare them for future career success, thus helping to meet a serious national need. We built a strong scaffolding of multiple mentors, social support, professional development, awareness of career opportunities, and technical training through interdisciplinary teams in close partnership with industry and national laboratory researchers. Our project offered first yea doctoral students the opportunity to move away from narrow disciplinary training, broadening their approaches to problem solving and their ability to work in diverse teams while also expanding their computational skills and familiarity with data analytic tools. Partnerships with colleagues in industry and the national laboratories furthered participants? career options and their readiness to collaborate with these institutions, regardless of whether they ultimately choose jobs in the academic or nonacademic sectors. Students interacted with peers and faculty across several disciplines, expanding their opportunities for collaboration, friendship, and support.

Specific objectives, which were met through a one-semester course and team projects, included:

1. Professionalization within the context of an interdisciplinary computational science research project

2. Team science and project management skills pertaining to managing knowledge-intensive projects

3. Fundamental research skills including writing scientific papers, literature reviews, scientific presentation, and research ethics

4. Computational skills including techniques for managing data, coding, data structures, visualization, and analytic techniques

5. Career preparation to work in and with industry and the national labs as well as the academy

Our pilot project exceeded our expectations in every way. In the five years since the program began, a total of 46 graduate students participated in the program. Twenty-six percent of them identify as Latinx and 8.7% as Black/African American, for a total of 35% Black or Latinx; 43% are women, and about three-quarters are first-generation students. Four of the program participants have graduated with a five year time to PhD (8.7%), 6 have left the university (13.0%), and 36 remain in good standing in their programs (78.3%). Of those who left the program, only 1/3 (2 students) were members of underrepresented groups. We consider this an amazing retention record, with an attrition rate of only 13% for students who have been in their programs for three to five years, given that most of the students are first generation and many are members of groups underrepresented in their disciplines. The project has met its overriding objective of increasing retention among this group of graduate students. We believe that part of our success lies in the supportive interface we created with other training programs emerging on campus, so students went from one source of support to another, interacting with peer and faculty from several computational disciplines. Thus, of the 46 participants in the program since its inception, 19 also participated in the Intelligent Adaptive Systems National Research Training, 5 participated in the NSF Center for Research Excellence in Science and Technology - Center for Cellular and Biomolecular Materials training grant, 2 in a NASA funded training grant, and 1 in our Alliance for Graduate Education and the Professoriate program. Two students in our program were recipients of the prestigious NSF Graduate Research Fellowship and one received a GEM fellowship; in all cases they received these fellowships after coming to UC Merced.

More information about our project, as well as links to students? team projects, may be found at https://graduatedivision.ucmerced.edu/deans-corner/grants/nrt-icge/overview.
